awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Jamming in Flexible Geometries-from Shape Sculpting to Shapeshifting
awd_abstract_narration:
NONTECHNICAL SUMMARY
This CAREER award supports theoretical research, education and outreach on jammed soft materials. Materials such as sand, glasses, foams and colloids can become rigid or jam as the density is increased. Jammed materials possess remarkable properties such as fragility and flowing readily if sufficient force is applied. These properties are due to their structure: particles in a jammed state have only the minimum number of neighbors required to hold them in place. 

The PI will investigate how the jamming process is altered when it occurs in a system that is changing shape, such as on a fluid droplet or an elastic body. A better understanding would enable the creation of materials and devices in applications that exploit shape, such as soft robotics, drug delivery systems, actuators, and artificial muscles. The PI will develop a computational model of jamming in flexible geometries and use it to determine how particles and initial shape affect the structure and how desired final shapes can be sculpted by carefully choosing the components of the system. By incorporating particles in the simulation that respond to external influences, such as in response to an applied field, or move under their own power, the research team will determine how these particles can be used to create shape-shifting materials that can change shape spontaneously. Computer software developed as part of this project will be made fully accessible to the community on public repositories.

This award also supports outreach and education efforts that are closely integrated with the research. The educational component aims to integrate soft matter and computation by incorporating projects and activities based on the research into the PI's newly developed course in Computational Physics. The outreach component will create and disseminate a web game, together with classroom materials developed by teachers, that communicates jamming to high school students and the general public. This award will also support the participation of Deaf and Hard of Hearing students in summer research at Tufts who will conduct simulations and analysis in support of the research. 

TECHNICAL SUMMARY
This CAREER award supports theoretical research, education and outreach on jammed soft materials. Jamming is a transition to rigidity that occurs in granular media. The goal of the research is to understand by computer simulations how the jamming transition is modified when it occurs in a flexible geometry. The central hypothesis of the proposal is that jammed states in flexible geometries constitute a new jamming category called "metric jammed" where the system is stable both with respect to collective motions of the surface and deformations of the manifold. Understanding how physical effects such as jamming are modified when shape and order co-evolve provides fundamental insight into these processes and will enable the creation of new materials, devices and industrial techniques such as soft robotics, drug delivery systems, actuators and artificial muscles that exploit the results. 

To test the central hypothesis, the PI will create a computational model of the metric jamming process and use this to: i) determine how shape and particles control the properties of the metric jammed state; ii) identify how flexible geometries affect metric jamming and how this can be used to sculpt soft colloidal particles of a desired shape; iii) incorporate actuatable and active particles into the model to determine how such particles can be used to create shape-shifting materials that can change shape spontaneously. This work will help advance the field of soft matter by providing a detailed understanding of the physics of the new metric jammed state in both two and three dimensions, the connections between order and shape change, the shapes that can emerge from these processes, and how microstructural changes can induce shape evolution. To help others navigate the numerous and complex physical effects intrinsic to this class of materials, the research will also provide open-source computational tools to facilitate this design.

This award also supports outreach and education efforts that are closely integrated with the research. The educational component aims to integrate soft matter and computation by incorporating projects and activities based on the research into the PI's newly developed course in Computational Physics. The outreach component will create and disseminate a web game, together with classroom materials developed by teachers, that communicates jamming to high school students and the general public. This award will also support the participation of Deaf and Hard of Hearing students in summer research at Tufts who will conduct simulations and analysis in support of the research.

por.por_cntn:
This project supported the study of fundamental physical principles underlying how materials that change shape may become rigid if the system also includes embedded particles. Particles are a key strategy to stabilize shape in soft matter where the particles can arrest and lock in a desired shape. Examples include coalescing or deformed Pickering emulsion droplets, mixtures of immiscible fluids such as oil and water with micron sized particles mixed in, bacteria and other biological media that grow on the surface of fluid droplets, and multicomponent gels.  While arrest is a commonly used strategy in preparing these and other materials, the underlying physics was poorly understood. 

Hence, the project sought to develop a general understanding of these processes that could guide researchers looking to exploit them to engineer particular shapes or structures, or control the mechanical and structural properties of shape-changing materials from their constituent ingredients. The project also aimed to link two powerful and distinct approaches to understanding particulate systems in complex geometries: One, often referred to as “spherical crystallography”, uses geometric and topological methods to understand how particles become organized on curved surfaces. The second, “jamming” concerns the transition to rigidity that bulk particulate media (e.g. sand) undergo as they are compressed. 

A major outcome of the project was the discovery of a new “metric jammed” state where solidification occurs on a surface, such as the interface between two fluids or an elastic membrane, that has been deformed from its initial state. As the surface returns to equilibrium, changing shape as it does, the particles may become crowded and rigidify, stabilizing the combined structure with respect to further deformation of the surface and collective motions of the particles. Using computer simulations, the project team generated representative structures in this class and analyzed their stability, mechanical properties and the arrangement of the particles. Generically, we found that arrested structures were not truly jammed, but could be unjammed and further evolved towards a final rigid state. Surprisingly, the mechanical properties of these final structures could be continuously tuned between those of bulk jamming and conventional elastic media by varying the particle’s stiffness.  A new type of vibrational mode was also discovered that involves simultaneous particle and shape deformation.

A second significant outcome is an apparent universality that emerges in that the organization of particles in these systems. Incorporating any kind of anisotropy into the system, e.g. using a distribution of particle sizes, or elongated particles rather than a sphere, disrupts the hexagonal crystalline order and introduces “defects”, particles with more or fewer than six neighbors. Importantly, these effects appear to be independent of the source of anisotropy. As the level of anisotropy increases, the defects form clusters. The size and structure of the clusters are well described by a mathematical model known as “percolation”, and provide a connection between crystalline and amorphous (disordered) states reminiscent of the Kosterlitz-Thouless-Halperin-Nelson-Young theory of melting. 

A highlight of the project is connections between theoretical work and experiments performed by collaborators. In addition to the results described above, work on the interaction and assembly of rigid hierarchical structures, spontaneous topography at the interface of structured fluids were performed within the scope of the project.

The project also generated significant outcomes through an integrated education and outreach program. This included the training of five PhD students who contributed to research connected with the grant, and six undergraduates who completed projects within its scope. Further, two DHH (Deaf or Hard-of-Hearing) interns participated in a summer internship on scientific computing using computer code developed in the grant. The project also built a valuable connection between Tufts Physics and Somerville High School, including two student summer interns and annual visits to judge the school science fair. Finally, in collaboration with education researchers, the PI devised a new approach to teaching computational physics called "computational making", inspired by the research itself and examples from Soft Matter and beyond. This new approach led to publications in the leading Physics Education Research journal and workshops for faculty interested in adopting this new approach.
